title: Wavefront Reconstruction Using Ray-Tracing
description: Analyze how interference patterns and diffraction form virtual and real images in a holographic plate using ray-tracing principles.
insight: Ray-tracing helps to mathematically describe how interference patterns encode spatial information, allowing virtual and real images to be reconstructed accurately.
question_text: A point object is placed at z = -500 mm along the optical axis in a Gabor holographic setup. The reference beam is a plane wave traveling parallel to the z-axis. Calculate the spatial frequency of the interference fringes at a point 50 mm above the optical axis on the hologram surface, given a He-Ne laser with a wavelength of 633 nm.

steps: **Step 1: Set up the spatial frequency equation**

title: Numerical Ray-Tracing: Image Position and Aberration
description: Use numerical ray-tracing to determine the image position and identify potential aberrations in a holographic system.
insight: Numerical ray-tracing helps accurately predict image positions and identify aberrations caused by beam geometry and recording parameters.
question_text: In a holographic imaging system, an object point is located 400 mm below the optical axis, and a reference beam is incident at an angle of 5° with respect to the optical axis. The recording wavelength is 633 nm, and the hologram is located 800 mm away from the object plane. Using numerical ray-tracing, determine the position of the reconstructed image along the z-axis.

solution.final_answer: The reconstructed image is located at approximately z = 823.6 mm.
steps: **Step 1: Write the image position formula from ray-tracing principles**
$$z' = \frac{z}{1 - \frac{z}{R}}$$, where R is the effective radius of curvature due to the reference beam.

title: Numerical Ray-Tracing: Image Shift Due to Reference Beam Angle
description: Use numerical ray-tracing principles to calculate the image shift caused by an angled reference beam in a holographic system.
insight: The angle of the reference beam introduces shifts in the reconstructed image position, which can be quantified through numerical ray-tracing.
question_text: In a holographic setup, an object is positioned 500 mm below the optical axis, and the reference beam makes an angle of 7° with the z-axis. The hologram is located 1000 mm from the object plane, and the laser wavelength is 532 nm. Using numerical ray-tracing, determine the lateral image shift caused by the reference beam angle.

solution.final_answer: The lateral image shift is approximately 122.1 mm.
steps: $$\Delta x = z \tan(\theta)$$, where $$z$$ is the object-to-hologram distance and $$\theta$$ is the reference beam angle.
The lateral image shift caused by the reference beam angle is approximately 122.1 mm.

The angle of the reference beam introduces a predictable lateral shift in the reconstructed image. This effect becomes more significant as the reference beam angle increases, requiring precise numerical ray-tracing for accurate corrections.
